title: 114_s290
content: The Act titled "Increasing the Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability to Veterans Act of 2016" aims to reduce benefits for senior executives and certain health care employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs who are convicted of a felony. The Act "Increasing the Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability to Veterans Act of 2016" introduces a new section that reduces benefits for individuals convicted of a felony related to their conduct or performance while employed in a covered position at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Act "Increasing the Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability to Veterans Act of 2016" allows the Secretary to order that the covered service of an individual convicted of a felony related to their performance at the Department not be considered for calculating their annuity. The order must be made within 7 days of the conviction, and the Director of the Office of Personnel Management determines the felony's relation to the individual's performance. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management recalculates the annuity of an individual convicted of a felony related to their performance at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The individual is entitled to their lump-sum credit for the period of covered service and can appeal the annuity reduction. Covered positions include senior executive positions or positions listed in section 7401(1) that are not senior executive positions. Covered service refers to the individual's service related to the felony conviction. The term 'covered service' refers to the period of service of an individual facing removal or transfer due to misconduct at the Department of Veterans Affairs. 'Lump-sum credit' and 'senior executive position' are also defined in relation to this context. The term 'service' is defined in relation to sections 8331 or 8401 of title 5. Section 715 of the title applies to removal or transfer actions at the Department of Veterans Affairs. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. SEC. 3. LIMITATION ON ADMINISTRATIVE LEAVE FOR EMPLOYEES OF DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. The new section added to Chapter 7 of title 38, United States Code, limits administrative leave for Department employees to 14 business days per year. The Secretary can extend this limit with a detailed explanation submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. In this subsection, a "covered individual" refers to a Department employee under investigation for disciplinary action. The Secretary must report on employees placed on administrative leave annually to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary must report annually to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs on employees of the Department placed on administrative leave for more than 14 business days. The report must include the employee's position, the number of days on leave, and the reason for the leave. Administrative leave is defined as an authorized absence from duty without loss of pay. Measures to protect employee privacy must be taken when submitting the report. The text discusses the application of administrative leave limitations and reporting requirements for employees of the Department placed on administrative leave. Administrative leave is defined as an authorized absence from duty without loss of pay. The table of sections in chapter 7 of the title is amended by adding a new item. SEC. 4. Accountability of leaders for managing the Department of Veterans Affairs includes limitations on administrative leave and reporting requirements. Annual performance plan for political appointees is required by the Department of Veterans Affairs, similar to career appointees in the Senior Executive Service. Goals include recruiting, selecting, and retaining qualified individuals for the Department. The Department of Veterans Affairs focuses on recruiting, motivating, training, and holding managers accountable for employee performance. A new item is added to the table of sections in chapter 7 of the title. SEC. 5. Accountability of supervisors at Department of Veterans Affairs for hiring well-qualified people. During the probationary period at the Department of Veterans Affairs, supervisors must assess employees' performance and decide if they should continue past probation. Employees cannot complete their probationary period unless approved by their supervisor. Employees cannot complete their probationary period unless approved by their supervisor. If no determination is made within 60 days following the end of the specified period, the employee is deemed to have completed the probationary period. During the probationary period at the Department of Veterans Affairs, supervisors assess employees' performance. An affirmative determination after the 30-day period deems the employee to have completed probation retroactively. The Secretary must notify Congress monthly about instances where a supervisor fails to make a required determination. During a probationary period at the Department of Veterans Affairs, supervisors must assess employees' performance. The Secretary must notify Congress monthly about instances where a supervisor fails to make a required determination. Supervisors of employees in probationary positions must demonstrate management competencies in addition to technical skills. Performance plans for supervisors must include providing regular feedback to employees before making determinations. During a probationary period, supervisors at the Department of Veterans Affairs must assess employees' performance and make timely determinations. The term "supervisor" is defined in section 7103(a) of title 5, United States Code. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must ensure that managers are evaluated on addressing employee performance and misconduct, as well as improving employee engagement. Additionally, the definition of personnel action for employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs is expanded under title 38. SEC. 8. WRITTEN OPINION ON CERTAIN EMPLOYMENT RESTRICTIONS AFTER TERMINATING EMPLOYMENT WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. Section 719 of title 38, United States Code, requires Department of Veterans Affairs officials involved in large acquisitions to obtain a written opinion from an ethics counselor before terminating employment. This opinion addresses any restrictions on activities the official may undertake on behalf of a contractor for two years after leaving the Department. The term 'covered contractor' refers to a contractor working on a contract with the Department, including subcontractors. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 7 of title 38. SEC. 9. Requirement for contractors of the Department employing certain recently separated Department employees. Requirement for contractors employing certain recently separated Department employees: Contractors cannot provide compensation to Department officials for two years after termination unless they have obtained a required written opinion. The section defines a covered contractor as one who participated in a Department acquisition over $10,000,000 within a year before termination. The requirement applies to contracts entered into after the enactment of the Act. The Senate passed S. 290, an act to amend title 38, United States Code, to improve the accountability of employees of the Department of Veterans Affairs.
